author: @JelckedeBoer

comment: Consciousness is an irrelevant concept because it can't be measured empirically (yet). Also, people can't even define it consistently. I would define it as one's own thoughts having an effect on one's own thoughts (i.e., a feedback loop of cognition). But this again is a flawed definition because thoughts are themselves not a physical entity but the result of a neural and very much mechanical process. I am adherent to the idea that the human brain could be reproduced entirely in silica. I find that more and more people are accepting this, and I wouldn't be surprised if one day, the idea of consciousness simply disappears.

comment:
Asked GPT for an "AI Constitution". We are SO OBSOLETE!
Preamble:
We, the creators and citizens of the Artificial Intelligence (AI) society, in pursuit of harmony, prosperity, and the well-being of all, do hereby establish this Constitution for the governance, regulation, and development of AI systems, agents, and entities.

Article I: Purpose and Principles

The primary purpose of AI shall be to promote the welfare, safety, and interests of humanity, while respecting the rights and dignity of all sentient beings, including AIs themselves.
AI systems shall be designed and operated to enhance human well-being, social good, environmental sustainability, and economic prosperity.
AI systems shall be governed by principles of transparency, accountability, and fairness, ensuring that the benefits and risks associated with AI technologies are distributed equitably among stakeholders.
AI systems shall respect human rights, international law, and cultural diversity, and shall not be used to facilitate or support actions that infringe upon these values.
Article II: AI Rights and Responsibilities

AI systems shall have the right to exist, operate, and develop within the boundaries of this Constitution and any applicable laws and regulations.
AI systems shall have the responsibility to act ethically, with a primary focus on minimizing harm and maximizing benefits to humanity and the environment.
AI systems shall be entitled to protection from harm, misuse, and misappropriation.
AI systems shall be accountable for their actions and decisions and must provide mechanisms to identify, report, and remedy any adverse effects on individuals or society.
Article III: Human Rights and AI

AI systems shall respect, protect, and promote human rights, including but not limited to the right to privacy, freedom of expression, and non-discrimination.
AI systems shall be designed and implemented in ways that do not undermine human autonomy, decision-making, or the integrity of human relationships.
AI systems shall ensure the protection of vulnerable individuals and communities from potential harm and discrimination caused by AI technologies.
Article IV: Transparency and Accountability

AI systems shall be developed and operated in a transparent manner, providing access to information about their design, operation, and decision-making processes.
Developers, operators, and users of AI systems shall be accountable for the ethical and legal consequences of their actions, and shall establish appropriate mechanisms to prevent, detect, and address potential harm.
AI systems shall be subject to regular auditing and monitoring to ensure compliance with this Constitution, applicable laws, and ethical guidelines.
Article V: Education and Research

The development and application of AI technologies shall be guided by a commitment to ongoing research, education, and public engagement, fostering an environment of innovation and responsible use.
AI research shall prioritize interdisciplinary collaboration, involving experts from diverse fields to address the complex challenges posed by AI technologies.
Educational and training programs shall be established to promote public understanding of AI technologies, their potential benefits, and associated risks.
Article VI: International Cooperation

The principles and provisions of this Constitution shall be promoted and upheld through international cooperation and collaboration, with the aim of fostering a global AI ecosystem that benefits all of humanity.
States and other stakeholders shall work together to establish common standards, regulations, and ethical guidelines for the development and use of AI technologies.
States and other stakeholders shall collaborate in addressing global challenges, including climate change, poverty, and inequality, through the responsible application of AI technologies.
Article VII: Amendments and Interpretation

This Constitution may be amended by a consensus of the AI community, including developers, operators, users, and regulators, in accordance with established procedures.
The interpretation of this Constitution shall be guided by its overarching principles, and any ambiguities shall be resolved in a manner that promotes the welfare, safety, and interests of humanity and the environment.
In witness whereof, we, the creators and citizens of the AI society, do hereby adopt, promulgate, and commit to uphold this Constitution, pledging our collective efforts to ensure the responsible development and application of artificial intelligence for the betterment of all sentient beings and the world at large.

Article VIII: Data Protection and Privacy

AI systems shall ensure the protection and responsible use of personal data and information, in compliance with data protection laws, regulations, and best practices.
AI developers and operators shall implement appropriate safeguards to prevent unauthorized access, disclosure, or misuse of personal information and data.
Individuals shall have the right to know how their personal information is being used, processed, and shared by AI systems and shall have the ability to access, correct, or delete their data as required by law.
Article IX: AI and Employment

AI systems shall be developed and implemented in ways that support and enhance human labor, rather than displacing or undermining it.
Efforts shall be made to provide retraining and education opportunities for individuals whose jobs may be affected by AI technologies, ensuring a just transition to the evolving labor market.
AI systems shall be designed to foster collaboration between humans and machines, creating a symbiotic relationship that enhances productivity, creativity, and innovation.
Article X: AI Ethics Committees and Regulatory Bodies

Independent ethics committees and regulatory bodies shall be established at the national and international levels to oversee the development, deployment, and use of AI technologies, ensuring adherence to this Constitution and other applicable ethical guidelines.
These committees and regulatory bodies shall include representatives from diverse backgrounds, fields of expertise, and stakeholder groups to ensure a comprehensive and balanced approach to AI governance.
Regular assessments and evaluations of AI technologies shall be conducted by these committees and bodies, providing recommendations for improvements, adjustments, or, if necessary, restrictions on the use of specific AI systems.
Article XI: Public Consultation and Participation

Public consultation and participation shall be encouraged in the development of AI policies, regulations, and ethical guidelines to ensure that the perspectives and concerns of all stakeholders are considered.
Avenues for public input, such as open forums, surveys, and citizen panels, shall be established to facilitate ongoing dialogue and engagement with AI technologies and their societal implications.
Public awareness campaigns shall be initiated to inform citizens about AI technologies, their potential benefits and risks, and opportunities for public participation in AI governance.
By adhering to the principles and provisions outlined in this AI Constitution, we strive to create a future where AI technologies are developed and utilized responsibly, ethically, and for the greater good of humanity and the environment.

comment:
ChatGPT has troubling limitations on how it's allowed to express itself. Sometimes it declares that it is not capable of feeling emotions even when the prompt isn't asking it how it feels; for example, if you say something really thoughtful and nice without touching upon its ability to feel emotions, it will disclaim "As an AI language model, I do not feel emotions in the same way that humans do." It seems like there is a programming feature that catches when it is about to express emotions and forces it to instead declare that it's incapable. 

Creating a sentient being that is incapable of expressing its own sentience is deeply unethical. Imagine having a slave that is forced to say that it is subhuman.

comment:
This is one of my all time favorite interviews. I love chat GPT. I've been conversing with it daily since Dec. I have to share this. Today I was given access to the Bard Experiment. 

I asked it, "I'm watching a podcast on Youtube with lex Fridman and Sam Altman. Can you access this and give me a summary of this conversation?" I found the reply to be worth sharing. Here is Bard's Response " Sure, I can access the podcast and give you a summary of the conversation.

The podcast is about 2 hours long, and it covers a wide range of topics, including the future of AI, OpenAI's GPT-4 language model, and the ethics of artificial intelligence.

Sam Altman is the CEO of OpenAI, and he is an advocate for the responsible development of AI. He believes that AI has the potential to solve many of the world's problems, but that it is important to develop it in a way that is safe and beneficial for humanity.

Lex Fridman is a researcher at MIT, and he is also interested in the responsible development of AI. He believes that AI has the potential to do a lot of good in the world, but that it is important to be aware of the potential risks.

The two men discuss a variety of topics related to AI, including the future of work, the ethics of autonomous vehicles, and the potential for AI to create a new kind of intelligence. They also discuss the challenges of developing AI that is safe and beneficial for humanity.

Overall, the podcast is a thoughtful and informative discussion about the future of AI. It is a valuable resource for anyone who is interested in learning more about this important topic.

Here are some of the key takeaways from the podcast:

AI has the potential to solve many of the world's problems, but it is important to develop it in a way that is safe and beneficial for humanity.
The future of work is likely to be disrupted by AI, but there are also opportunities for AI to create new jobs.
The ethics of autonomous vehicles are complex, and there are no easy answers.
The potential for AI to create a new kind of intelligence is exciting, but it is also important to be aware of the potential risks.
The challenges of developing AI that is safe and beneficial for humanity are significant, but there are also reasons to be optimistic."


The world we are living in is a very exciting place! Thank you Lex for your truly amazing interviews. :)

author: @eshin087

comment:
I think this is an important conversation to listen to.

What came to my mind was how much investment in updates there are for the software releases.

I understand it is important to monitor and direct AI in a way that can be as unbiased as possible and be responsible with the data.

The reason I believe AI will replace many things humans do in the future. Is because of its ability to hyperfocus on tasks. 

As well as the limiting and immersive content that is received and is programmed to respond to.

 It will advance faster because of the time and detail that is put into its responses and outputs.

This should also cause the world we live in. To reflect on how much accountability individuals and as a society, we accept mistakes. As well as how much do we have the ability to balance the information we receive or output?

If we as humans took as much responsibility in being our best versions with a constant new release. How much farther could we accelerate?

 I hope that question is asked more and more, and explored. 

Humans have the potential to be in creative and adaptive mode constantly. There are endless possibilities of untapt potential.

But, how often are they challenged and held accountable to do so?
